title: The Pilgrim’s Progress
description: A story of a man in search of truth told with the simple clarity and beauty of Bunyan’s prose make this the ultimate English classic.

title: Robinson Crusoe
description: By the end of the 19th century, no book in English literary history had enjoyed more editions, spin-offs and translations. Crusoe’s world-famous novel is a complex literary confection, and it’s irresistible.

title: Gulliver’s Travels
description: A satirical masterpiece that’s never been out of print, Jonathan Swift’s Gulliver’s Travels comes third in our list of the best novels written in English

title: Clarissa
description: Clarissa is a tragic heroine, pressured by her unscrupulous nouveau-riche family to marry a wealthy man she detests, in the book that Samuel Johnson described as “the first book in the world for the knowledge it displays of the human heart.”

title: Tom Jones
description: Tom Jones is a classic English novel that captures the spirit of its age and whose famous characters have come to represent Augustan society in all its loquacious, turbulent, comic variety.

title: The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman
description: Laurence Sterne’s vivid novel caused delight and consternation when it first appeared and has lost little of its original bite.

title: Emma
description: Jane Austen’s Emma is her masterpiece, mixing the sparkle of her early books with a deep sensibility.

title: Frankenstein
description: Mary Shelley’s first novel has been hailed as a masterpiece of horror and the macabre.

title: Nightmare Abbey
description: The great pleasure of Nightmare Abbey, which was inspired by Thomas Love Peacock’s friendship with Shelley, lies in the delight the author takes in poking fun at the romantic movement.

title: The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym of Nantucket
description: Edgar Allan Poe’s only novel – a classic adventure story with supernatural elements – has fascinated and influenced generations of writers.

title: Sybil
description: The future prime minister displayed flashes of brilliance that equalled the greatest Victorian novelists.

title: Jane Eyre
description: Charlotte Brontë’s erotic, gothic masterpiece became the sensation of Victorian England. Its great breakthrough was its intimate dialogue with the reader.

title: Wuthering Heights
description: Emily Brontë’s windswept masterpiece is notable not just for its wild beauty but for its daring reinvention of the novel form itself.

title: Vanity Fair
description: William Thackeray’s masterpiece, set in Regency England, is a bravura performance by a writer at the top of his game.

title: David Copperfield
description: David Copperfield marked the point at which Dickens became the great entertainer and also laid the foundations for his later, darker masterpieces.

title: The Scarlet Letter
description: Nathaniel Hawthorne’s astounding book is full of intense symbolism and as haunting as anything by Edgar Allan Poe.

title: Moby-Dick
description: Wise, funny and gripping, Melville’s epic work continues to cast a long shadow over American literature.

title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland
description: Lewis Carroll’s brilliant nonsense tale is one of the most influential and best loved in the English canon.

title: The Moonstone
description: Wilkie Collins’s masterpiece, hailed by many as the greatest English detective novel, is a brilliant marriage of the sensational and the realistic.

title: The Way We Live Now
description: Inspired by the author’s fury at the corrupt state of England, and dismissed by critics at the time, The Way We Live Now is recognised as Trollope’s masterpiece.

title: Kidnapped
description: A thrilling adventure story, gripping history and fascinating study of the Scottish character, Kidnapped has lost none of its power.

title: Three Men in a Boat
description: Jerome K Jerome’s accidental classic about messing about on the Thames remains a comic gem.

title: The Sign of Four
description: Sherlock Holmes’s second outing sees Conan Doyle’s brilliant sleuth – and his bluff sidekick Watson – come into their own.

title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
description: Wilde’s brilliantly allusive moral tale of youth, beauty and corruption was greeted with howls of protest on publication.

title: New Grub Street
description: George Gissing’s portrayal of the hard facts of a literary life remains as relevant today as it was in the late 19th century.

title: Jude the Obscure
description: Hardy exposed his deepest feelings in this bleak, angry novel and, stung by the hostile response, he never wrote another.

title: The Red Badge of Courage
description: Stephen Crane’s account of a young man’s passage to manhood through soldiery is a blueprint for the great American war novel.

title: Dracula
description: Bram Stoker’s classic vampire story was very much of its time but still resonates more than a century later.

title: Heart of Darkness
description: Joseph Conrad’s masterpiece about a life-changing journey in search of Mr Kurtz has the simplicity of great myth.

title: Sister Carrie
description: Theodore Dreiser was no stylist, but there’s a terrific momentum to his unflinching novel about a country girl’s American dream.

title: Kim
description: In Kipling’s classic boy’s own spy story, an orphan in British India must make a choice between east and west.

title: The Call of the Wild
description: Jack London’s vivid adventures of a pet dog that goes back to nature reveal an extraordinary style and consummate storytelling.

title: The Golden Bowl
description: American literature contains nothing else quite like Henry James’s amazing, labyrinthine and claustrophobic novel.

title: Hadrian the Seventh
description: This entertaining if contrived story of a hack writer and priest who becomes pope sheds vivid light on its eccentric author – described by DH Lawrence as a “man-demon”.

title: The Wind in the Willows
description: The evergreen tale from the riverbank and a powerful contribution to the mythology of Edwardian England.

title: The History of Mr Polly
description: The choice is great, but Wells’s ironic portrait of a man very like himself is the novel that stands out.

title: Zuleika Dobson
description: The passage of time has conferred a dark power upon Beerbohm’s ostensibly light and witty Edwardian satire.

title: The Good Soldier
description: Ford’s masterpiece is a searing study of moral dissolution behind the facade of an English gentleman – and its stylistic influence lingers to this day.

title: The Thirty-Nine Steps
description: John Buchan’s espionage thriller, with its sparse, contemporary prose, is hard to put down.

title: The Rainbow
description: The Rainbow is perhaps DH Lawrence’s finest work, showing him for the radical, protean, thoroughly modern writer he was.

title: Of Human Bondage
description: Somerset Maugham’s semi-autobiographical novel shows the author’s savage honesty and gift for storytelling at their best.

title: The Age of Innocence
description: The story of a blighted New York marriage stands as a fierce indictment of a society estranged from culture.

title: Ulysses
description: This portrait of a day in the lives of three Dubliners remains a towering work, in its word play surpassing even Shakespeare.

title: Babbitt
description: What it lacks in structure and guile, this enthralling take on 20s America makes up for in vivid satire and characterisation.

title: A Passage to India
description: EM Forster’s most successful work is eerily prescient on the subject of empire.

title: Gentlemen Prefer Blondes
description: A guilty pleasure it may be, but it is impossible to overlook the enduring influence of a tale that helped to define the jazz age.

title: Mrs Dalloway
description: Woolf’s great novel makes a day of party preparations the canvas for themes of lost love, life choices and mental illness.

title: The Great Gatsby
description: Fitzgerald’s jazz age masterpiece has become a tantalising metaphor for the eternal mystery of art.

title: Lolly Willowes
description: A young woman escapes convention by becoming a witch in this original satire about England after the first world war.

title: The Sun Also Rises
description: Hemingway’s first and best novel makes an escape to 1920s Spain to explore courage, cowardice and manly authenticity.

title: The Maltese Falcon
description: Dashiell Hammett’s crime thriller and its hard-boiled hero Sam Spade influenced everyone from Chandler to Le Carré.

title: As I Lay Dying
description: The influence of William Faulkner’s immersive tale of raw Mississippi rural life can be felt to this day.

title: Brave New World
description: Aldous Huxley’s vision of a future human race controlled by global capitalism is every bit as prescient as Orwell’s more famous dystopia.

title: Cold Comfort Farm
description: The book for which Gibbons is best remembered was a satire of late-Victorian pastoral fiction but went on to influence many subsequent generations.

title: Nineteen Nineteen
description: The middle volume of John Dos Passos’s USA trilogy is revolutionary in its intent, techniques and lasting impact.

title: Tropic of Cancer
description: The US novelist’s debut revelled in a Paris underworld of seedy sex and changed the course of the novel – though not without a fight with the censors.

title: Scoop
description: Evelyn Waugh’s Fleet Street satire remains sharp, pertinent and memorable.

title: Murphy
description: Samuel Beckett’s first published novel is an absurdist masterpiece, a showcase for his uniquely comic voice.

title: The Big Sleep
description: Raymond Chandler’s hardboiled debut brings to life the seedy LA underworld – and Philip Marlowe, the archetypal fictional detective.

title: Party Going
description: Set on the eve of war, this neglected modernist masterpiece centres on a group of bright young revellers delayed by fog.

title: At Swim-Two-Birds
description: Labyrinthine and multilayered, Flann O’Brien’s humorous debut is both a reflection on, and an exemplar of, the Irish novel.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
description: One of the greatest of great American novels, this study of a family torn apart by poverty and desperation in the Great Depression shocked US society.

title: Joy in the Morning
description: PG Wodehouse’s elegiac Jeeves novel, written during his disastrous years in wartime Germany, remains his masterpiece.

title: All the King’s Men
description: A compelling story of personal and political corruption, set in the 1930s in the American south.

title: Under the Volcano
description: Malcolm Lowry’s masterpiece about the last hours of an alcoholic ex-diplomat in Mexico is set to the drumbeat of coming conflict.

title: The Heat of the Day
description: Elizabeth Bowen’s 1948 novel perfectly captures the atmosphere of London during the blitz while providing brilliant insights into the human heart.

title: Nineteen Eighty-Four
description: George Orwell’s dystopian classic cost its author dear but is arguably the best-known novel in English of the 20th century.

title: The End of the Affair
description: Graham Greene’s moving tale of adultery and its aftermath ties together several vital strands in his work.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
description: JD Salinger’s study of teenage rebellion remains one of the most controversial and best-loved American novels of the 20th century.

title: The Adventures of Augie March
description: In the long-running hunt to identify the great American novel, Saul Bellow’s picaresque third book frequently hits the mark.

title: Lord of the Flies
description: Dismissed at first as “rubbish & dull”, Golding’s brilliantly observed dystopian desert island tale has since become a classic.

title: Lolita
description: Nabokov’s tragicomic tour de force crosses the boundaries of good taste with glee.

title: On the Road
description: The creative history of Kerouac’s beat-generation classic, fuelled by pea soup and benzedrine, has become as famous as the novel itself.

title: Voss
description: A love story set against the disappearance of an explorer in the outback, Voss paved the way for a generation of Australian writers to shrug off the colonial past.

title: To Kill a Mockingbird
description: Her second novel finally arrived this summer, but Harper Lee’s first did enough alone to secure her lasting fame, and remains a truly popular classic.

title: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
description: Short and bittersweet, Muriel Spark’s tale of the downfall of a Scottish schoolmistress is a masterpiece of narrative fiction.

title: Catch-22
description: This acerbic anti-war novel was slow to fire the public imagination, but is rightly regarded as a groundbreaking critique of military madness.

title: The Golden Notebook
description: Hailed as one of the key texts of the women’s movement of the 1960s, this study of a divorced single mother’s search for personal and political identity remains a defiant, ambitious tour de force.

title: A Clockwork Orange
description: Anthony Burgess’s dystopian classic still continues to startle and provoke, refusing to be outshone by Stanley Kubrick’s brilliant film adaptation.

title: A Single Man
description: Christopher Isherwood’s story of a gay Englishman struggling with bereavement in LA is a work of compressed brilliance.

title: In Cold Blood
description: Truman Capote’s non-fiction novel, a true story of bloody murder in rural Kansas, opens a window on the dark underbelly of postwar America.

title: The Bell Jar
description: Sylvia Plath’s painfully graphic roman à clef, in which a woman struggles with her identity in the face of social pressure, is a key text of Anglo-American feminism.

title: Portnoy’s Complaint
description: This wickedly funny novel about a young Jewish American’s obsession with masturbation caused outrage on publication, but remains his most dazzling work.

title: Mrs Palfrey at the Claremont
description: Elizabeth Taylor’s exquisitely drawn character study of eccentricity in old age is a sharp and witty portrait of genteel postwar English life facing the changes taking shape in the 60s.

title: Rabbit Redux
description: Harry “Rabbit” Angstrom, Updike’s lovably mediocre alter ego, is one of America’s great literary protoganists, up there with Huck Finn and Jay Gatsby.

title: Song of Solomon
description: The novel with which the Nobel prize-winning author established her name is a kaleidoscopic evocation of the African-American experience in the 20th century.

title: A Bend in the River
description: VS Naipaul’s hellish vision of an African nation’s path to independence saw him accused of racism, but remains his masterpiece.

title: Midnight’s Children
description: The personal and the historical merge in Salman Rushdie’s dazzling, game-changing Indian English novel of a young man born at the very moment of Indian independence.

title: Housekeeping
description: Marilynne Robinson’s tale of orphaned sisters and their oddball aunt in a remote Idaho town is admired by everyone from Barack Obama to Bret Easton Ellis.

title: Money: A Suicide Note
description: Martin Amis’s era-defining ode to excess unleashed one of literature’s greatest modern monsters in self-destructive antihero John Self.

title: An Artist of the Floating World
description: Kazuo Ishiguro’s novel about a retired artist in postwar Japan, reflecting on his career during the country’s dark years, is a tour de force of unreliable narration.

title: The Beginning of Spring
description: Fitzgerald’s story, set in Russia just before the Bolshevik revolution, is her masterpiece: a brilliant miniature whose peculiar magic almost defies analysis.

title: Breathing Lessons
description: Anne Tyler’s portrayal of a middle-aged, mid-American marriage displays her narrative clarity, comic timing and ear for American speech to perfection.

title: Amongst Women
description: This modern Irish masterpiece is both a study of the faultlines of Irish patriarchy and an elegy for a lost world.

title: Underworld
description: A writer of “frightening perception”, Don DeLillo guides the reader in an epic journey through America’s history and popular culture.

title: Disgrace
description: In his Booker-winning masterpiece, Coetzee’s intensely human vision infuses a fictional world that both invites and confounds political interpretation.

title: True History of the Kelly Gang
description: Peter Carey rounds off our list of literary milestones with a Booker prize-winning tour-de-force examining the life and times of Australia’s infamous antihero, Ned Kelly.
